Award.AwardTitle: Implementation Project Moving Forward - Steps to Graduate School

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Implementation Project entitled "Moving Forward - Steps to Graduate School" at Le Moyne-Owen College builds on a very successful previous project and has the overall goal to prepare minority undergraduate students with the skills and knowledge required to succeed in graduate school, with the aim to have them pursue careers in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) fields. The objectives of the project are: increased research and publications by students and faculty; faculty development; enhancement of the curriculum through honors courses; and methods designed to motivate students to matriculate in STEM majors. Activities focus on improvement of recruitment and retention rates; enrichment of the academic preparation of students; broadening and strengthening the undergraduate research program by improving the partnerships and collaborations in research with other academic institutions; industry and federal labs; and strengthening the faculty expertise as mentors and researchers by encouraging collaborative research and publications.

Le Moyne-Owen College enrolls mostly African American students, over sixty percent of whom are women. Most students come from disadvantaged socioeconomic backgrounds. The outcomes of this project will serve as a model for other minority-serving private institutions seeking to enhance STEM undergraduate instruction and research programs leading to increased participation of students in graduate school and subsequently the STEM workforce.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
LeMoyne-Owen College

Division of Natural & Mathematical Sciences

Implementation Award Outcomes Report

Moving Forward: Steps to Graduate School

 

Intellectual Merit

The overall objective of this program was to prepare minority undergraduates with the scientific knowledge and research skills required to succeed at the graduate level, with an aim to have them pursue careers in STEM disciplines. The key points of additional HBCU-UP Implementation grant support were increased research and publications; STEM faculty development; enhancement of the curriculum through honors courses; and methods designed to motivate students to matriculate in science. This proposed to increase the STEM knowledge of LOC faculty and students and, importantly, to help realize our three key goals of student recruitment, retention and graduation, as well as the continued development of faculty.

Broader Impact

LOC is an HBCU (Historically Black Colleges and Universities) serving a large minority population. The majority of students are female (over 60%) and most come from disadvantaged socioeconomic backgrounds. The Broader Impact will be felt far beyond the LOC campus via the placement of our students in graduate schools and the subsequent development of STEM researchers and instructors, which will have a perpetual impact. The outcomes of this project will serve as a model for other minority private institutions seeking to promote STEM undergraduate instruction and research programs.

 

Summary of Outcomes:

The specific objectives of this proposal and our results are as follows:

1)      To increase the recruitment and retention of STEM students resulting in an increase of total STEM enrollment from 124 to at least 150 students by the end of the project funding period.  While 2017-2018 was an outlier, the basic trend of STEM majors has been increasing and was 171 in 2018-2019

2)      To increase the number of STEM graduates annually from 11 to 17 by the end of the project funding period.  The number of STEM graduates has been steadily increasing since 2013, but took a major jump to 28 graduates in 2019 as a direct result of our Moving Forward Program.

3)      To increase the number of graduating seniors who enter graduate school to a minimum of 6 per year by the end of the funding period.  We have 4 STEM graduates from the class of 2019 who have been accepted and will be attending graduate school in their field of study.  While this is shy of our goal of 6, we have an additional 4 students who were accepted into pre-professional school through a direct partnership that the college implemented last year with University of Tennessee Health Science Center College of Nursing.  Additionally, we anticipate at least 5 graduates from the class of 2020 to attend graduate school.

 

STEM majors and graduates by year.

Additional Gains from this program:

 1.  In addition to producing STEM graduates, we have seen that many of our participants have become prominent leaders at the college through the student development that this program has encouraged.

2.  A curriculum was developed and incorporated into the college course offerings that encourage students to investigate and prepare for graduate school while pursuing their BS degree.  Eight courses, two at each class level, were designed to progress students from entry college level through GRE prep and applying to graduate school.  These courses include:  MFWD101:  Excelling in College (2), MFWD102:  Introduction to STEM Research (2), MFWD201: STEM Research I (2),  MFWD202: STEM Research II (2),  MFWD301: Graduate Program Selection (1),  MFWD302: GRE Preparation (3),  MFWD401: Graduate Application (2),  and MFWD402: Excelling in Graduate School (2).  While the research courses are limited to STEM majors, the other are open to all majors.

3.  An out-growth of our MFWD program is a graduate school tour program called GPS (graduate and professional school) exposure.  These trips are open to all majors who meet a minimum GPA requirement.

4.  Students who have participated in research have presented at local, regional, and/or national conferences and been able to network with graduate school recruiters.  Several students have also been included as authors on papers that have been accepted into peer reviewed journals thus giving them an advantage when applying to graduate school programs.

5.  This program continues to facilitate the research mind-set on our campus for both our students and faculty. 

 


Last Modified: 12/13/2019
Modified by: Sherry Painter
